definitions: small room or hall between entrance door and interior of building
chamber or channel in the body serving as entrance to another structure
examples: Visitors waited in the vestibule before entering the mansion
The church vestibule displayed community announcements and donation boxes
Sound waves enter through the vestibule of the inner ear
The vestibule connects the semicircular canals to the cochlea

definitions: trace or remnant of something that once existed but has largely disappeared
examples: The ruins are the last vestiges of the ancient civilization
Not a vestige of doubt remained after seeing the evidence

definitions: veterinarian who provides medical care for animals
person who has served in the armed forces
examples: The vet examined our dog's injured paw carefully
She took her cat to the vet for annual vaccinations
The Vietnam vet shared stories from his service days
Many vets struggle with readjustment to civilian life

definitions: person who has served in the armed forces especially during wartime
person with long experience in a particular field or activity
examples: The veteran received medals for his service in Afghanistan
Veterans Day honors all who served in the military
She's a veteran teacher with thirty years in the classroom
The veteran journalist covered conflicts on three continents

definitions: medical professional trained and licensed to treat diseases and injuries in animals
examples: The veterinarian performed emergency surgery on the injured horse
Our veterinarian specializes in exotic pets like reptiles and birds

definitions: branch of medicine dealing with prevention and treatment of disease in animals
examples: She studied veterinary medicine at the state university
The veterinary clinic offers services for both pets and livestock

definitions: constitutional right to reject a decision or proposal made by lawmakers
exercise of authority to reject or prohibit something
examples: The president threatened to veto the controversial spending bill
The governor's veto prevented the tax increase from becoming law
Her parents put a veto on the weekend trip plans
The committee chair exercised his veto over the proposal

definitions: ability to work successfully or continue to exist and develop properly
examples: Investors questioned the viability of the startup's business model
The doctor assessed the viability of the premature infant

definitions: long bridge-like structure carrying a road or railway across a valley or low ground
examples: The train crossed the valley on a nineteenth-century stone viaduct
The highway viaduct spans the river and surrounding wetlands

definitions: small bottle typically used for holding liquid medicines or samples
examples: The nurse prepared several vials of blood for testing
She kept the perfume in a delicate crystal vial

definitions: distinctive emotional atmosphere or feeling sensed from person, place or situation
examples: The coffee shop had a relaxed, friendly vibe
I got bad vibes from that abandoned warehouse

definitions: quality of being full of energy, life, and enthusiasm
examples: The vibrancy of the street market attracted tourists from everywhere
Her paintings captured the vibrancy of tropical landscapes

definitions: rapid back and forth movement of particles in an elastic medium
distinctive emotional sensation or atmosphere
examples: The vibration from the construction work shook the entire building
Engineers measured vibrations in the bridge during the stress test
She felt positive vibrations from the meditation group
The room held vibrations of past celebrations and gatherings

definitions: device that produces vibratory motion for various purposes including massage or industrial applications
examples: The concrete vibrator removed air bubbles from the poured foundation
Physical therapists use vibrators to relieve muscle tension

definitions: priest in the Anglican Church who is in charge of a parish
examples: The vicar conducted Sunday services at the village church
She consulted the vicar about arranging her daughter's baptism

definitions: immoral or wicked behavior or harmful habit
tool with movable jaws for holding work firmly
position of deputy or assistant in title
examples: Gambling became his most destructive vice over the years
The detective investigated vice crimes in the city district
He secured the wood piece in the vice before sawing
The mechanic's vice held the engine part steady
She served as vice president of the company
The vice admiral commanded the naval fleet

definitions: area near or surrounding a particular place
examples: Several restaurants operate in the vicinity of the hotel
Police searched the vicinity for the missing child

definitions: person harmed, injured, or killed as result of crime, accident, or other action
examples: The victim of the robbery identified the suspect in a lineup
Flood victims received emergency shelter and food supplies

definitions: action of singling out someone for cruel or unjust treatment
examples: The report documented patterns of victimization in the workplace
Victimization of elderly people through scams has increased significantly

definitions: person who defeats an enemy or opponent in battle, game, or competition
examples: The victor raised his arms in triumph after the match
History books are often written by the victors

definitions: act of defeating an enemy or opponent in battle, game, or other competition
examples: The team celebrated their victory with champagne and cheers
Her victory in court set an important legal precedent

definitions: recording of moving visual images made digitally or on videotape
examples: She uploaded the video to her social media account
The security video captured the entire incident clearly

definitions: sight or prospect seen from particular place especially beautiful scenery
particular way of considering or regarding something
act of looking at or inspecting something
examples: The hotel room had a spectacular view of the ocean
Mountain views stretched for miles in every direction
Her view on education reform differs from the mainstream
From my view, the project needs more funding
Schedule a view of the property with the real estate agent
The art gallery attracted thousands of views last month

definitions: person who watches television programs, films, or other visual content
device for looking at photographic slides or other images
examples: Millions of viewers tuned in for the season finale
The documentary shocked viewers with its graphic footage
She examined the slides through the stereo viewer
The vintage viewer displayed old vacation photographs

definitions: device on camera showing the area that will appear in photograph
examples: She looked through the viewfinder to compose the perfect shot
The electronic viewfinder displayed exposure settings and focus points

definitions: act of watching film, television program, or other visual content
occasion when something is available to be looked at or inspected
examples: The family enjoyed their viewing of the classic movie
Late-night viewing often includes reruns and infomercials
The house viewing attracted several potential buyers
Public viewing of the body will be held Thursday evening

definitions: particular attitude or way of considering a matter
place from which someone can see something, especially scenic area
examples: Try to understand the issue from different viewpoints
Her viewpoint on immigration has evolved over the years
The viewpoint offered panoramic vistas of the valley below
Tourists gathered at the viewpoint to photograph the sunset

definitions: period of keeping awake during normal sleeping time especially to keep watch or pray
examples: Protesters maintained a vigil outside the embassy for weeks
The family kept vigil at her hospital bedside

definitions: action or state of keeping careful watch for possible danger or difficulties
examples: Constant vigilance is required to prevent cyber attacks
The guard's vigilance prevented the security breach

definitions: member of self-appointed group undertaking law enforcement without legal authority
examples: The vigilante took justice into his own hands
Vigilantes patrolled the neighborhood after the recent crimes

definitions: practice of ordinary citizens taking law enforcement into their own hands
examples: The rise in vigilantism worried local law enforcement officials
Vigilantism often leads to miscarriage of justice and violence

definitions: brief evocative description, account, or episode in literature or film
decorative design or small illustration used in books or other printed material
examples: The novel included vignettes of life in rural America
Each vignette captured a moment of childhood innocence
The chapter opened with an ornate vignette of flowers
Victorian books often featured elaborate vignettes on title pages

definitions: physical strength, energy, and enthusiasm in activities or qualities
examples: She attacked the problem with renewed vigor and determination
The plant grew with surprising vigor in the greenhouse

definitions: physical strength, energy, and enthusiasm in activities or qualities
examples: He pursued his studies with great vigour and dedication
The vigour of youth gradually fades with age

definitions: large and luxurious country house in its own grounds
holiday home especially in southern Europe often rented to tourists
examples: The Roman villa had beautiful mosaic floors and gardens
They own a villa overlooking the Mediterranean Sea
We rented a villa in Tuscany for our summer vacation
The villa sleeps eight people and has a private pool

definitions: group of houses and associated buildings in rural area smaller than town
examples: The village had only five hundred residents and one store
She grew up in a fishing village on the coast

definitions: person who lives in a village
examples: The villagers gathered in the square for the annual festival
Local villagers opposed the construction of the new highway

definitions: character in story or play who opposes the hero
person guilty of or responsible for crime or wrongdoing
examples: The villain revealed his evil plan in the final act
Children booed when the villain appeared on screen
Police finally caught the villain behind the fraud scheme
He was portrayed as the villain in the scandal

definitions: wicked or criminal behavior characteristic of a villain
examples: The detective exposed the villainy behind the charitable organization
His villainy knew no bounds as he plotted revenge

definitions: energy and enthusiasm in expression or action
examples: She tackled the project with vim and vigor
His vim and vitality impressed everyone at the meeting

definitions: action of clearing someone of blame or suspicion and proving them right
examples: The court ruling was complete vindication of her actions
He sought vindication after years of false accusations

definitions: person who clears someone of blame or proves something to be right or justified
examples: History proved to be his vindicator in the controversy
She became a vindicator for those wrongly accused

definitions: plant with long thin stem that grows along ground or climbs supports
examples: Grape vines covered the entire south wall of the house
The jungle vines made passage through the forest difficult

definitions: sour-tasting liquid containing acetic acid obtained from wine, cider, or other fermented liquids
examples: She dressed the salad with olive oil and balsamic vinegar
White vinegar works well as a natural cleaning agent

definitions: plantation of grapevines typically producing grapes for winemaking
examples: The vineyard produced award-winning wines for three decades
They toured several vineyards in the Napa Valley

definitions: informal term for wine especially cheap or ordinary wine
examples: Let's grab some vino for the party tonight
The restaurant served decent vino at reasonable prices

definitions: year or place in which wine was produced
period when something was produced showing its quality and characteristics
denoting something from the past of high quality representing best of its era
examples: The 1982 vintage is considered exceptional for Bordeaux wines
This bottle is from a particularly good vintage
His car collection includes vehicles of various vintages
Music from that vintage still sounds fresh today
She wore a vintage dress from the 1950s
The shop specializes in vintage clothing and accessories

definitions: strong flexible plastic material used in various products
gramophone records made of vinyl as a music medium
examples: The kitchen floor was covered with durable vinyl tiles
Vinyl siding protects the house from weather damage
He collects vintage vinyl from the 1960s and 1970s
Many musicians still release albums on vinyl

definitions: stringed instrument of violin family slightly larger than violin with deeper tone
plant of genus that includes pansies and violets
examples: She played viola in the school orchestra for four years
The viola section provides rich middle tones in the symphony
Purple violas bloomed in the window boxes all summer
The garden featured violas in various bright colors

definitions: action of breaking or failing to comply with rule, law, or formal agreement
examples: The company faced fines for violation of safety regulations
Parking violations result in tickets and possible towing
